thread.title: Harry Redknapp believes Liverpool are no better off under Jurgen Klopp than they were under Brendan Rodgers
thread.title_full: Harry Redknapp believes Liverpool are no better off under Jurgen Klopp than they were under Brendan Rodgers

author: irishmirror
title: Harry Redknapp believes Liverpool are no better off under Jurgen Klopp than they were under Brendan Rodgers
text:
Harry Redknapp believes Liverpool are no better off under Jurgen Klopp than they were under Brendan Rodgers Redknapp has stuck the boot in following the Reds' poor run of recent form Share Liverpool have struggled since the turn of the year (Photo: Leicester City FC via Getty Images) Share Get   Thank you for subscribing!   
Former Tottenham boss Harry Redknapp says Liverpool are no better off under Jurgen Klopp than they were under Brendan Rodgers - and believes a Sunday League team would give them a decent game. 
Redknapp has stuck the boot in following the Reds poor fun of form in 2017, report the Liverpool Echo . 
And the father of former Liverpool skipper Jamie believes that summer signing Joel Matip “isn’t up to it” and the Reds are paying the price for poor recruitment in recent years. 
And Redknapp insists the current squad pales in comparison to Rodgers’ title challengers of 2013-14 and hasn’t improved since Klopp’s arrival. Redknapp is not a fan of Matip (Photo: REUTERS) 
“Everyone got carried away with Jurgen Klopp’s appointment but Liverpool are no better off than they were two years ago,” he said. 
“They were at their best in 2013-14 with Raheem Sterling, Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge scoring goals for fun under Brendan Rodgers. 
“You thought ‘My God, whoever you stick in behind them, it doesn’t matter because those three will rip teams to pieces’. Redknapp was a big fan of Rodgers' side (Photo: Ben Hoskins/Getty) 
“Suarez was the best player in the Premier League, Sterling’s pace frightened teams every week and Sturridge was at the top of his game. Now you look at them and they don’t terrify you in the same way.” 
Writing in his latest column for the Evening Standard , Redknapp believes fans and pundits were guilty of being too easily won over by Klopp during his early weeks in charge at Anfield, but nevertheless reckons the Reds can continue their impressive record against top-six clubs when Arsenal visit on Saturday evening.
